He just cut a deal with the E.U. in which he got the E.U. to agree to immediate purchase of soybeans. So he is using the European Union, his pressure on the European Union on trade to get them to help American farmers to counteract Chinese retaliatory tariffs. That's three-dimensional chess.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: If the market is any measure, Juan. If the market is any measure, there was definitely some nervousness in the U.S. stock market and today like what it sought, triple digit gains.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, I just think that you have to -- the president likes to, you know, art of the deal start by making very strong demands. And then say, well, and I think this is what happened yesterday. I don't think there is any deal, Marc, with the European Union, I think what you have is the president saying, we are going to talk. We are now open and we won't have a trade war before the midterms. And so slow down on that. But there's no real deal yet and we still have this--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: All right. Last word on that. I got to get to Jim Jordan, Marc.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: Yes. The Europeans agreed to buy U.S. soybeans right away, and they put out a joint statement--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. That's (Inaudible).

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: -- they put out a joint statement saying they are going to zero tariffs, zero trade barriers and zero subsidies on non-auto--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Not realistic, Marc. Not realistic. That's why I say until we see the specifics then I can buy--

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: The Europeans buy--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So far the president doesn't have anything on the table except his promise, you know, we'll be great again.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Well, he made a visit to those states today and he made a few folks happy, you saw him up on the stage, on the stages. The rates for the speakership, it is certainly heating up, Marc. I want to ask you about Jim Jordan throwing his hat in the ring.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: Yes. So, you know, Jim Jordan is not going to be the speaker. He doesn't have the votes to become the speaker and he's running despite some very serious allegations that have been made by wrestlers at OSU. That when he was an assistant coach, the team doctor was abusing wrestlers and they reported it to him and he ignored it. Now he denies those charges. But you know, we just had a situation where a Republican speaker, Dennis Hastert, turned out to have been a molester of wrestlers. That's the last thing we want for the Republican Party is to have anything to do with allegations of people abusing or ignoring abuse of wrestlers. So I think it's a bad move for conservatives and for the Republican Party--

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: In his announcement he criticizes the current GOP leadership, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think that's what this is about, I think that he doesn't want Kevin McCarthy, the congressman from California to become the next speaker. He doesn't see him as sufficiently, you know, respectful of the Freedom Caucus. Jim Jordan is a member of that right wing caucus in the House. So if you get Kevin McCarthy blocked, I think then Steve's Scalise, the congressman from Louisiana who is more conservative has a better chance.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: He's another LSU tiger. You just -- they're all over the place tonight. Hey, Marc Thiessen and Juan Williams, good to have both of you on the program tonight. Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're welcome.

utterances.speaker: THIESSEN
utterances.utterance: Great to be with you.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Coming up, the White House now pushing back on why they banned a CNN reporter from a Rose Garden event. Guy Benson and Marie Harp, look at those two, the co-host of the new Benson and Harp Fox News radio show are here next on the growing debate. Plus a former Special Forces sniper and a UFC fighter and said he just tried not to die as he took on some of the most dangerous jobs in the country. And Tim Kennedy lives to tell about it. And he will join us live, next.

utterances.speaker: TIM KENNEDY, UFC FIGHTER
utterances.utterance: Am I doing this first one?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Do you think you could do it?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think so.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: The White House disputing reports that a CNN reporter was banned from covering an event yesterday. Press secretary Sarah Sanders explaining the reporter, quote, "shouted questions and refused to leave despite repeatedly being asked." Fox News media analyst Howie Kurtz reports on the growing controversy.

utterances.speaker: HOWARD KURTZ, FOX NEWS MEDIA ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Sandra, the media controversy erupted when CNN White House reporter Kaitlan Collins, among others, were shouting questions at President Trump after an Oval Office photo op.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN WHITE HOUSE REPORTER
utterances.utterance: Did Michael Cohen betray you, Mr. President?

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: Thank you. Thank you, everybody.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: Mr. President, did Michael Cohen betray you? Why has Vladimir Putin not accepted your invitation?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Thanks, everybody.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: This is a pretty routine practice but White House officials were not pleased and barred Collins from attending a later event. This is what she says press secretary Sarah Sanders and Deputy Chief of Staff Bill Shine, a former co-president of Fox News, told her.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.utterance: That I would not be invited to an open press event here in the Rose Garden moments later at the White House because they thought the questions I posed to President Trump were inappropriate and inappropriate for that venue.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: But Shine disputed that account this morning.

utterances.speaker: BILL SHINE, WHITE HOUSE DEPUTY CHIEF OF STAFF
utterances.utterance: Did you ask her if you ever used the word ban. I've seen it on lower thirds?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: What word did you use, Bill?

utterances.speaker: SHINE
utterances.utterance: What word would you use?

utterances.speaker: SHINE
utterances.utterance: When you ask her if we ever use the word ban, then I will answer that question.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: If it is her, what's the word you would use?

utterances.speaker: SHINE
utterances.utterance: You ask her, focus now. You asked her if we ever used the word ban.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: See and then called the move retaliatory because the White House didn't like Collins' questions. And Fox News president Jay Wallace said, "We stand in strong solidarity with CNN for the right to full access for our journalist as part of a free and unfettered press."

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: As a member of the White House press pool, Fox stands firmly with CNN on this issue of access.

utterances.speaker: MARTHA MACCALLUM, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: She is a member of the White House pool and should be treated as such and not isolated.

utterances.speaker: KURTZ
utterances.utterance: The bottom line is reporters have been shouting questions at presidents for decades going back to Sam Donaldson and Ronald Reagan. The practice may be more frequent with President Trump now because he often answers such questions even as his press handlers are suing people out. Sandra?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Howie. Here with me now, making their first live TV appearance as the host of Benson and Harp on Fox News radio. Guy Benson and Marie Harf, looking good, guys.

utterances.speaker: MARIE HARF, FOX NEWS RADIO CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS RADIO CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Thank you, Sandra.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Good evening to you. All right. So first off, I want you both to weigh in on this. The White House barring this reporter and it has certainly sparked a big debate in this country. To you first, Guy.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: Well, I think I was immediately reminded, Sandra, of something that happened in 2009 when the Obama administration tried to freeze out our network, Fox News, from asking questions of a senior administration official in fall of that year. And the other networks all banded together including CNN and they said it, no, if Fox is not included in this process, none of us are going to do it. And the Obama administration relented and backed down. I think what we saw there from Jay Wallace, our president here at the network and Bret Baier and Martha MacCallum was paying that forward back to CNN because I think it is important regardless of who is in power, regardless of which administration happens to occupy 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. The White House press corps is a team together and they stand up for the First Amendment, they stand up for their ability to gain access and not be isolated or thrown out of the press corps based on partisan or ideological differences. And so the show is on the other foot and I'm glad that our network has come down on the side that we have.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Well, Marie, the White House is certainly pushing back here. And Kellyanne Conway was on this network earlier today reacting. Watch.

utterances.speaker: KELLYANNE CONWAY, WHITE HOUSE SENIOR ADVISER
utterances.utterance: I think that the question isn't -- or the questioner ask a lot of questions. This president obviously isn't afraid of questions, we answer them routinely. It's -- I think being, and that incident aside, just being polite to the process to the presidency and to the protocol, and not shouting questions long after the press has politely been asked to leave, long after that we have an opportunity to be there with the president. I think it's a very reasonable request.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Marie?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well, look, reporters in those scrums with the president always shout questions, that's what happens. It's happened for decades under multiple presidents of different parties. So what Kellyanne said doesn't really stand up to what the practice has been. And look, this is the latest in a series of White House versus CNN, particularly, the White House versus the press showdown. This is a White House that has called or president who has called the press the enemy of American people on multiple occasions. I think the president and the White House thrive in some respects on battling the press and they know their base likes it. So we have to see this as the latest in a series really of actions of the White House trying to freeze out reporters whose stories they don't like, calling stories fake news that are actually true but they just don't like them, so it is disturbing. And I'm really glad that our network and all the networks have stood up for CNN and I hope it doesn't continue because it's a really bad look for this- -

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: Although as the president, he does go too far sometimes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Way too far.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: But the press and the media is extraordinarily biased against this president and his administration. There is no denying that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Well, speaking of that, Twitter in the news today and we know that Twitter has been used as a major political tool by the president and others. And Twitter appears to have updated its policy now after the shadow banning conservative's controversy. Twitter issued the statement on the GOP's shadow banning report, saying, quote, "We are aware that some accounts are not automatically populating in our search box, and shipping a change to address this. The profiles, tweets, and discussion about these accounts do appear when you search for them. To be clear, our behavioral ranking doesn't make judgments based on political views or the substance of tweets." But this has raised a lot of questions, Guy.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, I think a lot of conservatives look at Silicon Valley and big tech and are deeply suspicious if those companies which are sort of in the deep blue territory run by very liberal people are going to give conservatives speech a fair shake. And I think that Twitter is right to acknowledge what's going on here rather than calling it a conspiracy theory. They are acknowledging this has gone on. It seems like they are altering their algorithms and their policies which is the right thing to do. And I think conservatives should remain not always accusatory but at least vigilant and hold big tech accountable. I'm actually going to Twitter out in San Francisco to their headquarters next week and I'm probably pretty certain this topic is going to come up--

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: For sure.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: -- because these rules have to be applied evenly to all sides.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And they also have bigger problems to when it comes to harassment and bullying and across the political spectrum, so Twitter has a lot of issues they need to deal with.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Well, this is the first live shot of taking you both inside of your radio, so this was exciting.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.utterance: Welcome in.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Thank you very much.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: It's good, right?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Thank you for having us in tonight. Good to see you both, Guy and Marie. Benson and Harf, I should say. Thank you very much. Up next, it's being described as a mix between dirty jobs and fear factor. A former UFC fighter and Green Beret takes on some of the country's most dangerous jobs and lives to tell about it. Tim Kennedy joins us next with a sneak peek of his new show.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Tim Kennedy is a thrill seeker. The former UFC fighter, ranger, Green Beret and Special Forces sniper is now taking on a new adventure in the Discovery Channel news series, 'Hard to Kill.' From flying planes to escaping a sinking boat, Tim has learned the most dangerous jobs of unsung heroes. Here's a sneak peek.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: All right. You want to try those?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: All right. So I'm going to give you the control so we get up on that, Mr. Kennedy?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Am I doing this first one?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Do you think you can do it?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think so.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: We are going to push the nose down and we're going to accelerate to 140 knots on your speed indicator. We're going to pull the nose through the horizon so your feet are just about on the horizon, does that make sense?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: And you watch the horizon come around.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I don't need anything besides a stick, right? There's no throttle, there's no--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: I will take care of everything else.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: All right. Show it to me. You have the control.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: You have my attention. Joining me now is Tim Kennedy, star of Hard to Kill which premiers Tuesday on Discovery. What were you thinking when you were watching that just now?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It just reminds me how stupid I am.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Don't say that.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: It's true.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: You are an accomplished -- you are a hero indeed. Why are you doing this?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I mean, Iraq, Afghanistan, Africa, South America, I've been all over the world in a military and went a green hatch, I've been up a plane get shot at and blown up.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And you wanted more?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No, no. I wanted it to be for a reason, you know. And the reason is there are some courageous bro, people right here in the middle, right here in the middle of America.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: So why you've been putting the show together? Who are these teams?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I've seen courageous people doing jobs that are thought -- that are thankless that nobody recognize, nobody thinks of.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: First of all, the guy we were watching you said that guy crashed -- has crashed three planes?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. Yes. Elliot.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: What was going on there?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: He's a test pilot. One of the episodes that we feature is like we get on planes, right. We get on a 747 and 737 we want our peanuts and we want our beverage service, and we want to go for a flight but we never think all--

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: And we want to be on time.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. We want to be on time. There's people that have flown those planes. There's no test dummies, there's no crash test dummies, there is a dude that sits in that plane or a lady that is courageous and is like, let's see if it flies. Right? And that's how aviation excels. That's how we get oil in our cars. That's how we get sushi on our table as there is someone on a boat that could die, go overboard or could freeze to death and I think they are kind of the unsung heroes of this beautiful country and this thing that we have the American dream.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: In one episode you attempt to survive, which obviously we know you did a sinking boat?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No. I mean, yes. But the boat was on fire and we were trapped inside of it and my safety gear was inside of the hole. So, actually as the boat sank I had to swim in. I got tore up and cut and I had to take up a Tomahawk and smashed through the window and swing through the window. None of this was planned, there are no stunts. It's like, hey, Tim, the boat is on fire and you are going to drown. Good luck with that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Have you said no to anything?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: No. No. Our limitation is always, you know, insurance is like weight, you want to a set plane on fire inside of another plane and put you inside of that plane and pushed it out of that plane with your blindfold and your parachute strapped to a chair behind you.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Two arms, two legs, two feet, it's like you survived like, do you have any major injuries from any of this?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. I got run over by a bull pretty bad.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: A bull.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes, a 2,000 pissed off bull. And he hooked me, and threw me up in the air, and then turned around and was like, I'm not done with you. And he came back for more.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Because you are experiencing being a bull rider for that?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. You mean, bull fighter.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: A bull fighter.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes. Being scared to death and being trapped in the avalanche at the base of a mountain for 30 minutes. Being like, hey, you're going to find me and you can't move and you don't know which was is up, and every time you breathe, there is a little bit less air. You know, that is also like one -- don't want to do again list.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Amen to you for going out there. There are lots of unsung heroes. What has stuck with you the most through this process?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I'm inspired.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Like I find these men and women that do these jobs. You know, it's not like I do them for a week or two weeks or maybe a month, like these people get up every single day not for a year, not for 40 years but for generations. Like their dad did it and their dad's dad did it and they had 10 cousins and now they had six because four of them died and they went into the drink. But this is what their family does. You know, they maybe commercial fishermen. And it's just this humbling, every single day. It's just I got a thought I'm a tough guy, no, like looking at these people and what they do and how they provide for us and how they make America beautiful and powerful and great, it's humbling and inspiring to be around these people.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: OK. So you are married, right?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: What's your wife think about this?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: She is like, this idiot, you know, could he just go be an accountant or something, you know, like maybe?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: But that's just not you, right?

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I could never do it. There is nothing else I can do. This is what I'm made to do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: All right. Tim Kennedy, the show 'Hard to Kill' premiers Tuesday, July 31st. That's next Tuesday at 10 p.m. Eastern on Discovery.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: We will be tuning into that for sure.

utterances.speaker: KENNEDY
utterances.utterance: I hope so, you'll like it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Thank you so much for joining us tonight. Great to meet you. More on 'The Story,' next.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.utterance: Well, that's it for our 'Story' on Thursday night. Don't miss Sean Hannity's exclusive interview with Roseanne Barr, that is coming up at 9 p.m. Eastern Time tonight. One hour from now. I will see again you bright and early tomorrow morning on America Newsroom from 9 a.m. till 12 noon. Join Bill and me every weekday at that time, hashtag nine to noon. Tucker Carlson is up next. Thank you again for joining us.
